translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Kaṇikāra Trees
The Story of the Elder Tālapuṭa
“The Fortunate One named Sataraṁsī,
self-existent, unconquered,
after emerging from seclusion,
went out for alms.
Seeing me with a fruit in my hand,🔽I approached the bull of men;
with a confident mind, happy,
I gave a palm fruit.
For ninety-four aeons,
the fruit I gave then,
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of giving a fruit.
My defilements have been burned up,
I live without defilements.
It was surely a good thing for me,
I have done what the Buddha asked.
The four analytical insights,
I have done what the Buddha asked.”🔽Thus the elder Tālapuṭa recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā tālaphaladāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Tālaphaladāyakattherassāpadānaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā tālaphaladāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽tālaphaladāyaka therassa apadānam navama
translated: The Story of the Elder Tālapuṭa is the ninth.
